learning_outcomes.description: Describe properties and clinical applications of dental materials used in prosthodontics
Apply the knowledge of the properties and applications of dental materials in prosthodontic practical activities
Demonstrate an understanding of scientific principles of radiation and radiation safety
Describe the epidemiology, aetiology, pathology and prevention of gingivitis and mild periodontal disease
Demonstrate the effective use of periodontal instruments to perform supragingival debridement
Demonstrate the ability to learn from experiences and apply critical reflective learning skills to dental practice

assessments.task_description:
The purpose of this assessment is to evaluate the student’s pre-clinical/peer clinic performance at the interim stage and provide formative feedback to support improvement before the final clinical competence assessment at the end of semester.

Course Coordinator in consultation with the pre-clinical/peer clinic supervisory team will complete a report based on student’s clinical performance during the assessment period and quality of critical self-reflections following each session.

See Submission Guidelines for all components that must be submitted for the interim clinical practice performance task to be assessed. Detailed assessment criteria and rubrics will be provided on Blackboard.

Two domains will be assessed to an expectations met (EM) or not met (ENM) standard and mapped to the Professional competency requirements for the accreditation body for this program - The Australian Dental Council (Professional Competencies of the newly Qualified Dentist)

The domains being assessed are: 

1. Professionalism, Communication and Health Promotion 

2. Clinical Treatment and Evaluation

To achieve a pass, the criteria are as follows:

All domains are weighted equally, and the student must achieve a pass in each domain, and an overall pass.

  • A pass in each domain will involve a student receiving 3 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark in Domain 1, and no more than 3 "expectation not met" (ENM) in Domains 2. 
  • An overall pass for the report will involve a student receiving 6 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark across the 2 domains.


Please note:

  • Written feedback will be provided for any areas to improve as this is formative. Students must reflect on feedback and demonstrate improvement in the latter half of the semester.
  • Logbooks may be randomly audited by the Course Coordinator for authenticity and supervisor signatures.
  • Any significant clinical concerns related to safety will be escalated immediately via course coordinator pathways and documented and taken into consideration for the assessment outcomes.


There is no resubmission or resit available for this component. This is a formative assessment to enable the student to receive feedback on their developing clinical competency.

Any significant clinical concerns pertaining to patient safety will be escalated via clinical communication pathways to the course coordinator and recorded on this report to be considered for the assessment outcome.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Detailed marking rubric for this assessment is available on blackboard. See Submission Guidelines for all components that must be submitted for the portfolio to be assessed for this clinical practice performance task.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Notebook/ Logbook, Performance, Practical/ Demonstration, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
The purpose of this assessment is to evaluate the student’s pre-clinical and peer clinic performance for this course, at the end of the semester. Course Coordinator in consultation with the pre-clinical/peer clinic supervisory team will complete a report based on student’s pre-clinical /peer clinic performance during the assessment period and quality of critical self-reflections following each session.

Students are advised to review any feedback provided in the interim report, to improve pre-clinical/peer clinic performance, in the latter part of his course, to pass this final clinical practice performance assessment which is must pass to pass this course.

Detailed marking rubric for this assessment is available on Blackboard.

See Submission Guidelines for all components that must be submitted for this clinical practice performance task to be assessed. The submitted portfolio will be reviewed and performance in each domain considered and used to complete a report of overall performance in each domain as per the criteria and standards.

The clinical portfolio will be reviewed and performance in each domain considered and used to complete a report of overall performance in each domain.

Two domains will be assessed to an expectations met (EM) or not met (ENM) standard and mapped to the professional competency requirements for the accreditation body for this program - The Australian Dental Council (Professional Competencies of the newly Qualified Dentist)

The domains being assessed are: 

1. Professionalism, Communication and Health Promotion 

2. Clinical Treatment and Evaluation

Passing requirements:

To pass this assessment, students must achieve a pass on this summative assessment on clinical performance progress at this stage. To achieve a pass, the criteria are as follows:

All domains are weighted equally, and the student must achieve a pass in each domain, and an overall pass.

  • A pass in each domain will involve a student receiving 3 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark in Domain 1, and no more than 3 "expectation not met" (ENM) in Domain 2. 
  • An overall pass for the report will involve a student receiving 6 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark across the 2 domains.


Students must complete all required components as outlined in Submission Guidelines for the portfolio submission.

Please note:

  • Written feedback provided for any areas to improve from the interim task, must be reflected on and student should demonstrate improvement in the latter half of the semester to enable passing of this must pass task.
  • Logbooks may be randomly audited by the Course Coordinator for authenticity and supervisor signatures.
  • Any significant clinical concerns related to safety will be escalated immediately via course coordinator communication pathways and documented in the report and taken into consideration for the final assessment outcome.


In accordance with PPL Assessment Procedure Section 3 Part J, supplementary assessment will not be available for this final clinical practice performance task, as professional competencies are developed over a 13-week practicum. There is no resubmission or resit option available for this assessment either.ﾠ
assessments.submission_guidelines: The submitted portfolio must be COMPLETE in all the following respects and submitted by the published due date which will then be assessed as part of this assessment task. Any incomplete or missing information can result in a fail grade in this must pass assessment task.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The exam will be held in-person via Inspera during normal preclinic time, in week 7. The exam will be for 60 mins duration. Please arrive 15 mins early to allow for ID check and set up in Inspera.


Students will need a laptop for this exam with Inspera safe browser installed. If you do not have a laptop with access to the internet (connect to Eduroam) - you may be able to borrow a laptop from the Library (https://web.library.uq.edu.au/library-and-student-it-help/using-library-devices/laptop-loans).


The exam may contain a mixture of multiple-choice questions (MCQ), problem solving such as match the following, fill in the blanks, and/or short answer questions (SAQ). The exam will be worth 50 marks in total and will cover content from all learning activities in weeks 1-6 inclusive. 


See Blackboard for Task Description and marking criteria document for more details.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The exam will only be available in Inspera Assessment for the duration of your exam. You will not be permitted to click START until directed to do so by your Exam Invigilator.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The Multiple Station Assessment Task will be conducted in Week 11.


The MSAT will have multiple working stations with a set duration between 3-10 mins each. Students will be rotated around all the stations and be asked to demonstrate competency to one or more learning objective/s for DENT2070. Students will also be expected to present and conduct themselves professionally.


During the MSAT, students can expect to answer questions, draw and explain diagrams, perform practical tasks, demonstrate concepts by role-playing, communicating understanding orally and in written form. The MSAT provides an assessment of the student’s knowledge and skills acquired from self directed modules (UQ Extend), applied concepts from clinical teaching sessions and acquired practical skills from laboratory sessions. All aspects explored in DENT2070 are examinable, with particular emphasis on practical and applied concepts.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Answer booklets will be handed in at the completion of the MSAT.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will be held in-person via Inspera in the scheduled end of semester examination block. The exam will be for 60 mins duration. Please arrive 15 mins early to allow for ID check and set up in Inspera.


Students will need a laptop for this exam with Inspera safe browser installed. If you do not have a laptop with access to the internet (connect to Eduroam) - you may be able to borrow a laptop from the Library (https://web.library.uq.edu.au/library-and-student-it-help/using-library-devices/laptop-loans).


The exam may contain a mixture of multiple-choice questions (MCQ), problem solving such as match the following, fill in the blanks, drag and drop labels, and/or short answer questions (SAQ). The exam will be worth 60 marks in total. It will cover content from learning activities in weeks 7-12 inclusive.


See Blackboard for Task Description and marking criteria document for more details.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(23 Feb - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Face to Face Instruction

Weekly 2-3 hour face to face series including prosthodontics, periodontics and radiology. Wednesday 1-4 pm in Auditorium. Student attendance is compulsory at face to face clinical coaching sessions, that will be case based in nature.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 11(23 Feb - 17 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Preclinical

Simulation laboratory activities: A series of sessions in the preclinical simulation laboratory will be scheduled through the semester. Further detailed timetables will be available on the Blackboard course site. Attendance is compulsory, and will be monitored. Weekly activities will be held including prosthodontic and periodontic sessions in Preclinic Lab 1 from 9-12 am. Students should arrive at 8:45am to set stations for a 9 am start.


Learning outcomes: L02, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Preclinical Simulation laboratory activities: A series of sessions in the preclinical simulation laboratory will be scheduled through the semester. Further detailed timetables will be available on the Blackboard course site. Attendance is compulsory, and will be monitored. Weekly activities will be held including prosthodontic and periodontic sessions in Preclinic Lab 1 from 9-12 am. Students should arrive at 8:45am to set stations for a 9 am start.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 13(13 Apr - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Peer Clinic

Peer to peer clinical group work (week 7-13):

Clinical skills training will be undertaken in the OHC clinics under the direct supervision of a qualified dentist. Attendance is compulsory and will be monitored. Clinical experience should be recorded in a year 2 clinical experience log book and form the basis of the Critical Reflection VLOG assessment.

Peer clinic activities will take place on Mondays 9-12 am (Group 1) and 1-4 (Group 2) from week 7-13 in Clinic 3.4 A. Students should arrive 15 mins early for group instructions and set up to start promptly at 9 am and 1 pm respectively.


Learning outcomes: L02, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Peer Clinic Peer to peer clinical group work (week 7-13): Clinical skills training will be undertaken in the OHC clinics under the direct supervision of a qualified dentist. Attendance is compulsory and will be monitored. Clinical experience should be recorded in a year 2 clinical experience log book and form the basis of the Critical Reflection VLOG assessment. Peer clinic activities will take place on Mondays 9-12 am (Group 1) and 1-4 (Group 2) from week 7-13 in Clinic 3.4 A. Students should arrive 15 mins early for group instructions and set up to start promptly at 9 am and 1 pm respectively.

As these are workshops, attendance is compulsory.
